0: For the people still bothering to drive to the Bogle seeds farm in Hamilton to snap a selfie with a sunflower, Barry and Marlene Bogle have a message — 'Go home. We're closed.' NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Bogle's have 1.6 million sunflower plants on 68 acres. And for more than a week, you could roam part of their field and take a picture before you head home. It cost $7.50 per adult, parking included. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It was a great idea for eight days. Then it became too great. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Everything went wrong. People were coming in, trespassing, knocking down our plants, stealing the heads. It was just chaos. - Barry Bogle, Bogle Seeds NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Up until Saturday it was just another wonderful day at Bogle Seeds here," Barry Bogle said, "but soon as Saturday came it's just been so stressful." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "People started coming in from every direction in the farm and just thousands of people walking past our ticket booth." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Barry says some people cut the heads off the sunflowers, didn't bother paying for tickets, left garbage and " just basically took over our farm." Some, Barry says, even went as far as bringing a ladder into the field. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR His son Brad, the sixth-generation of Bogles farming the land since 1874, described Saturday as a "zombie apocalypse." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Bogle Seeds, a farm offering people the opportunity to take photos with their sunflowers was forced to close on Saturday after far too many people showed up. They say photo opportunities are likely closed forever. All roads backed up with traffic, people parking on the side of the highway, people trying to cross the highway ... even saw a fender bender while leaving." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The wild bird seed farm is in the Hamilton area of Flamborough at Highway 6 and Safari Road — a busy and often dangerous stretch of highway. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Police arrived and thank goodness they kind of helped out and put the massive traffic jam under control a little bit," said Bogle. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At around 2 p.m. the Bogles decided to shut things down.
